newsitem.title: SPAIN: SOCCER-BARCELONA CRASH TO 4-0 DEFEAT AT TENERIFE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BARCELONA CRASH TO 4-0 DEFEAT AT TENERIFE.

text.p: Barcelona's beleaguered coach Bobby Robson saw his plight worsen on Saturday when two of his players were sent off in a 4-0 Spanish league defeat at Tenerife.
Former England manager Robson refused to discuss his position at the club in a post-match press conference.
Second-placed Barcelona were left six points adrift of leaders Real Madrid, who would go nine points clear with a win at Espanyol on Sunday.

Wins for Deportivo Coruna and Atletico Madrid -- who move to within three and four points of Barcelona respectively -- have also reopened the race for Spain's second European Cup Champions' League place.
Robson blamed his team's bad run on poor refereeing.
"I think we had a penalty -- that's important ... we need those decisions, at the moment we get bad decisions against us, we need good decisions for us," said Robson afterwards.

Barcelona went behind to a Felipe Minambres goal after just six minutes, and could find no way back after losing defenders Miguel Angel Nadal and Abelardo Fernandez to red cards for last-ditch challenges.
Slavisa Jokanovic scored from a penalty as a result of one of the fouls, and converted another before completing his hat-trick seven minutes from time.
"(With) the red card for Abelardo, the game was over," said Robson, who took off several key players to rest ahead of next week's European Cup Winners' Cup game with AEK Stockhom
In other games, international midfielder Jose Luis Caminero scored twice to lead Atletico Madrid to an important 3-2 victory over Sevilla.
But Caminero went to bed immediately after the game because of stomach problems and is doubtful for Wednesday's vital European Cup tie at Ajax.
Another point in front ahead of Atletico are Deportivo Coruna, who continued their recovery by winning 2-1 at Rayo Vallecano with goals from midfielders Corentin Martins and Rivaldo.
